title: Dräger Fabius Anesthesia Machine - Ventilator Fails Self-Test / Won’t Start
description: Guide for troubleshooting a Fabius anesthesia machine ventilator that fails self-test or won't start, focusing on external causes and patient safety.

steps.title: Ensure Power Supply and Connection
steps.instructions: Confirm the machine is plugged into a verified hospital-grade outlet. Check that the main power switch is ON. Inspect the power cord for damage. Why it matters: Anesthesia machines will not complete self-tests without stable power.

steps.title: Check Backup Battery Status
steps.instructions: If the machine uses a battery, verify it is charged and properly seated. Some Fabius models require a battery to be functional to pass self-test.

steps.title: Verify Gas Supply and Hoses
steps.instructions: Ensure all medical gases (O₂, N₂O, air) are connected and pressure is within specification. Confirm that the hoses are properly attached and there are no leaks. Why it matters: Gas pressure sensors can prevent self-test completion if insufficient.

steps.title: Inspect Breathing Circuit and Accessories
steps.instructions: Remove any patient circuit attachments, filters, or breathing bags that may obstruct the system. Ensure that the ventilator circuit is properly mounted and clamps are released. Why it matters: Obstructions or misaligned components can cause self-test failure.

steps.title: Check for Active Alarms or Fault Indicators
steps.instructions: Review the display for messages that may indicate sensor errors, disconnected components, or service reminders.

steps.title: Power Cycle the Machine
steps.instructions: Turn off the machine, wait 30–60 seconds, and restart. Why it matters: A simple reset often clears temporary faults in software or sensors.

steps.title: Run Self-Test with Minimal Configuration
steps.instructions: Disconnect optional modules or accessories. Run self-test again to see if the issue persists.

CCR.Complaint: Ventilator fails self-test and will not start; machine displays error code during pre-use check.
CCR.Cause: Power supply and gas connections verified; breathing circuit removed; self-test continues to fail, suggesting internal ventilator or sensor fault.
CCR.Resolution: Machine removed from service, labeled Out of Service, and sent for Dräger bench evaluation/service.

helpfulDetails: Machine status: Out of Service pending repair.

title: Dräger Fabius Anesthesia Machine – Battery / UPS Problems
description: Troubleshooting guide for battery faults, charging issues, and UPS transition problems on the Dräger Fabius anesthesia machine.

steps.title: Ensure Patient Safety First
steps.instructions: Do not troubleshoot while the machine is supporting an active patient unless absolutely necessary. If there is a battery or power failure alarm during a case, ensure the patient is safely transitioned to backup ventilation and stable before proceeding.

steps.title: Verify AC Power Source
steps.instructions: Confirm the power cord is fully seated in both the rear of the Fabius and the wall outlet. Check for a secure hospital-grade plug connection. Look for any damage to the power cord (cuts, bent prongs, loose strain relief). Test the outlet with a known-good device or outlet tester. A poor AC supply prevents the internal battery from charging and may trigger battery alarms.

steps.title: Check Power Indicator Lights
steps.instructions: Verify the machine indicates AC power present. Confirm no facility power interruptions occurred (tripped breaker, switched outlet, power strip). If connected to an external UPS, verify the UPS is powered on and not in fault mode.

steps.title: Simulate Power Loss (When Safe and Off Patient)
steps.instructions: With the unit powered on and not in clinical use, disconnect AC power. Confirm the unit transitions to battery power without shutting down. Observe for immediate low battery alarms or shutdown. If the unit shuts down immediately, suspect battery degradation or internal power supply issues.

steps.title: Check Battery Status Indicators
steps.instructions: Review battery charge percentage on the display. Note whether the battery appears to charge when AC power is restored. If battery percentage remains static or drops quickly, battery capacity is likely diminished.

steps.title: Consider Battery Age
steps.instructions: Review service records for battery replacement history. Internal batteries in anesthesia machines commonly degrade over 2–4 years depending on usage and environment. If beyond expected lifespan, battery replacement is appropriate.

steps.title: Inspect for Environmental Factors
steps.instructions: Check for excessive heat around the machine. Listen for abnormal fan noise. Note any burnt smell or unusual heat near the power supply area. These may indicate internal power supply or charging circuit concerns.

steps.title: Check External UPS (If Used)
steps.instructions: Confirm external UPS runtime is adequate. Perform a controlled UPS self-test. Replace UPS batteries if they fail load testing. Ensure the issue is not external before attributing failure to the anesthesia machine.

CCR.Complaint: Anesthesia machine alarming for low battery and shuts down when unplugged.
CCR.Cause: Battery failed load test. Unit powered off immediately when AC disconnected. Battery age 4+ years.
CCR.Resolution: Replaced internal battery pack. Verified proper charging and confirmed successful transition to battery power during simulated power loss test.

title: Dräger Fabius Alarm Failures / False Alarms
description: Guide for troubleshooting false alarms or alarm failures on Dräger Fabius anesthesia machines.

steps.title: Verify Machine Power and Backup
steps.instructions: Ensure the machine is plugged into a verified working outlet and powered on. Check battery status if operating on internal battery.

steps.title: Inspect Alarm and Sensor Connections
steps.instructions: Verify that all breathing circuits, O₂ sensors, pressure lines, and flow sensors are properly connected. Check that connectors are clean, dry, and free of damage.

steps.title: Check Gas Supply and Flow
steps.instructions: Confirm that O₂, N₂O, and air supply lines are connected and pressure is within normal operating range. Verify that flowmeters are not blocked or leaking.

steps.title: Examine Breathing Circuit Setup
steps.instructions: Ensure correct circuit type (adult, pediatric) is selected in the machine settings. Check for leaks or obstructions in the circuit and endotracheal tube connections.

steps.title: Confirm Alarm Configuration and Limits
steps.instructions: Review the alarm limits set in the machine for O₂, CO₂, airway pressure, tidal volume, etc. Ensure that alarm mute buttons are not inadvertently engaged.

steps.title: Perform a Self-Test / System Check
steps.instructions: Run the machine’s built-in self-test (Dräger Fabius includes an automated check). Observe any errors or warnings reported.

steps.title: Environmental Factors
steps.instructions: Ensure the machine is not exposed to extreme temperatures, moisture, or electrical interference. Remove any nearby equipment that could interfere with sensors.

CCR.Complaint: User reports frequent false alarms and occasional alarm failures on the Fabius machine.
CCR.Cause: Upon inspection, some sensor connectors were loose, and alarm limits were improperly set.
CCR.Resolution: Reconnected sensors securely, verified all connections, reset alarm limits, ran self-test, and confirmed alarms functioning correctly.

helpfulDetails: Any unusual sounds or smells: Describe

title: Dräger Fabius Touchscreen / Display Errors
description: Troubleshooting guide for Dräger Fabius anesthesia machine touchscreen and display issues, focusing on external causes before internal component failure.

steps.title: Ensure Patient Safety First
steps.instructions: Confirm the machine is not actively ventilating a patient before troubleshooting. If in use, transition the patient to another anesthesia machine or alternate ventilation source first. Display troubleshooting should never compromise patient ventilation.

steps.title: Verify AC Power and Battery Status
steps.instructions: Confirm the unit is plugged directly into a known-good outlet. Check for tripped breakers or recently used red emergency outlets that may have unstable supply. Review battery status on the screen (if visible). Low voltage or unstable power can cause screen freezes, flickering, or boot issues. Verify outlet tested, power cord secure at both ends, no extension cords, and no power strips.

steps.title: Perform a Controlled Reboot
steps.instructions: If safe and the machine is not in use, power down the machine using proper shutdown procedure. Wait 30–60 seconds. Restart the system and observe boot behavior. Observe whether the screen initializes normally, startup tones are normal, and whether the display fails before or after full boot. If the screen restores after reboot, the issue may have been a software hang.

steps.title: Inspect for External Physical Causes
steps.instructions: Check for visible screen cracks or fluid intrusion. Look for condensation or OR cleaning residue near bezel edges. Confirm no adhesive covers or protective films are interfering with touch response. Touchscreens can become unresponsive due to fluid intrusion or contamination.

steps.title: Check for Peripheral Lockups
steps.instructions: If the screen appears frozen but the machine is powered, observe whether alarms are functioning. Check if knobs or physical buttons respond. Disconnect any non-essential external connections (network, USB if applicable). If physical controls work but touchscreen does not, the issue may be isolated to the display module.

steps.title: Evaluate Environmental Factors
steps.instructions: Determine if the OR experienced temperature extremes, if the machine was recently moved from cold storage, or if there is visible heat buildup or fan obstruction. Overheating or condensation can cause temporary display malfunction.

steps.title: Observe for Backlight vs. Display Failure
steps.instructions: If the screen appears blank, shine a flashlight at the screen. If faint images are visible, possible backlight issue. If completely dark with no image, possible display power or control issue. This helps differentiate between backlight failure and total display loss.

CCR.Complaint: Touchscreen not responding to touch in OR 3. Screen frozen during case setup.
CCR.Cause: Unit powered but touchscreen unresponsive. Reboot temporarily restored function. Issue recurred after 15 minutes. No external contamination noted.
CCR.Resolution: Removed anesthesia machine from service. Labeled Out of Service. Scheduled vendor repair for suspected display module failure.

title: Dräger Fabius Anesthesia Machine - Low Oxygen Pressure / O₂ Flush Issues
description: Guide for troubleshooting low oxygen pressure or O₂ flush issues on a Dräger Fabius anesthesia machine.

steps.title: Verify Oxygen Supply
steps.instructions: Check that the oxygen cylinder or pipeline supply is full and turned on. Confirm the correct pressure at the machine inlet using the pressure gauge. Why it matters: Low or empty supply is the most common cause of low oxygen pressure alarms.

steps.title: Inspect Hoses and Connections
steps.instructions: Visually inspect the oxygen hose from the source to the machine. Ensure all connections are tight and free of kinks, cracks, or leaks. Why it matters: Even small leaks can reduce pressure and prevent the O₂ flush from functioning properly.

steps.title: Check the Oxygen Flowmeter
steps.instructions: Verify that the flowmeter knob is in the correct position. Ensure the flowmeter tube and bobbin move freely. Why it matters: Obstructions or misalignment can prevent proper flow and pressure.

steps.title: Test O₂ Flush Function
steps.instructions: Press the O₂ flush button briefly. Observe whether the oxygen flows rapidly into the circuit. If the flush is weak or absent, note any unusual sounds or behavior. Why it matters: A faulty flush valve or blocked pathway may indicate internal components need servicing.

steps.title: Check for Machine Alarms or Messages
steps.instructions: Review the display panel for any error messages related to oxygen supply or pressure. Follow any suggested external corrective actions listed by the machine.

steps.title: Power Cycle the Machine
steps.instructions: Turn the machine off and back on per manufacturer instructions. Confirm if the low oxygen pressure alarm persists. Why it matters: Some sensors or valves may reset after power cycling.

CCR.Complaint: Low oxygen pressure alarm and weak O₂ flush observed.
CCR.Cause: Oxygen cylinder was low and supply hose had a minor kink reducing flow.
CCR.Resolution: Replaced cylinder, straightened hose, verified O₂ flush function; machine returned to service.

title: Dräger Isolette C2000 Infant Incubator – Touch Panel / Control Knob Not Responding
description: Troubleshooting guide for unresponsive touch panel or control knob issues on the Dräger Isolette C2000 infant incubator, focusing on external checks before internal repair escalation.

steps.title: Ensure the Infant Is Safe Before Troubleshooting
steps.instructions: Confirm the infant is stable. If active patient care is involved, transfer the infant to another functioning incubator before performing troubleshooting. Never power cycle during active neonatal support. Patient safety always comes first.

steps.title: Verify Power Source and Power Quality
steps.instructions: Confirm the unit is plugged into a tested hospital-grade outlet. Check that the outlet is functioning (use an outlet tester if needed). Verify the AC power indicator is illuminated. Check for recent power interruptions or brownouts reported by staff.

steps.title: Check for Panel Lock or Keypad Lock Function
steps.instructions: Confirm the control panel is not in “Lock” or “Standby” mode. Attempt to unlock per normal user interface steps. Verify no lock indicator icons are displayed.

steps.title: Inspect the Touch Panel Surface
steps.instructions: Look for residual cleaning solution, moisture, cracked overlay, delamination, or sticky residue. Gently clean the surface with approved disinfectant and dry thoroughly.

steps.title: Assess Control Knob Function
steps.instructions: Rotate the knob slowly and observe if values change. Press inward (if push-to-select style) and observe for feedback. Check for mechanical binding, uneven rotation, or excessive looseness.

steps.title: Perform a Controlled Power Cycle (If Safe)
steps.instructions: Only perform this step if the infant has been transferred and no therapy is actively dependent on this incubator. Turn the unit off using the normal shutdown process. Wait 60–90 seconds. Restore power. Observe whether the screen boots normally, touch response returns, or any error codes appear.

steps.title: Observe for Additional Symptoms
steps.instructions: Document any delayed screen refresh, random beeping, display flicker, alarm messages, or burning smell or abnormal heat near control panel.

CCR.Complaint: NICU staff reported the incubator control panel was not responding to touch, and temperature settings could not be adjusted.
CCR.Cause: Touch panel remained unresponsive after cleaning and power cycle. Control knob rotation did not change settings. No external power issues found. Likely internal UI interface failure.
CCR.Resolution: Unit removed from service, labeled Out of Service, and sent to shop for further evaluation. Replacement incubator provided to unit.

helpfulDetails: Final device status (Removed from service / Operational after reboot)

title: Dräger Isolette C2000 Infant Incubator – Temperature Control Errors (Too Hot / Too Cold)
description: Troubleshooting guide for Dräger Isolette C2000 temperature control errors, including overheating, underheating, and failure to maintain setpoint.

steps.title: Ensure Patient Safety First
steps.instructions: If the incubator is actively being used, transfer the infant to another verified working incubator before troubleshooting. Do not attempt troubleshooting while supporting a patient inside the unit. Why: Temperature instability can directly impact neonatal safety.

steps.title: Verify Mode of Operation (Air Mode vs. Skin Mode)
steps.instructions: Confirm whether the incubator is operating in Air Temperature Mode or Skin (Servo) Mode. Verify the correct setpoint for the selected mode. Why: Incorrect mode selection can create perceived overheating or underheating.

steps.title: Check Skin Probe (If in Servo Mode)
steps.instructions: Ensure the skin probe is securely connected to the incubator. Inspect the probe cable for damage. Confirm proper probe placement on the infant (abdomen, secure adhesion). If available, test with a known good probe. Why: A disconnected or faulty probe can cause runaway heating or false low-temperature readings.

steps.title: Inspect Air Temperature Sensor Area
steps.instructions: Check that the internal air sensor is not obstructed. Look for buildup of lint, debris, or residue. Why: Obstructed airflow around the sensor can cause inaccurate readings.

steps.title: Check Doors, Access Ports, and Seals
steps.instructions: Ensure all portholes and access doors are fully closed. Inspect door gaskets for gaps or damage. Why: Air leaks commonly cause low-temperature alarms or inability to maintain setpoint.

steps.title: Inspect Air Circulation
steps.instructions: Listen for the circulation fan operating normally. Check for unusual noise or lack of airflow. Ensure nothing is blocking internal air vents. Why: Poor circulation leads to temperature stratification and control instability.

steps.title: Evaluate Heater Function
steps.instructions: In a safe, empty unit, monitor temperature rise from ambient to setpoint. Confirm steady, gradual temperature increase. Watch for overshoot beyond setpoint. Why: Overshoot may indicate sensor calibration issues or control instability. Failure to heat suggests heater or power delivery problems.

steps.title: Verify Calibration Status
steps.instructions: Review last preventive maintenance date. If temperature deviation is suspected, compare displayed temperature with a calibrated external thermometer during controlled testing. Why: Sensor drift over time can cause inaccurate control.

steps.title: Check for Error Codes or Alarm Messages
steps.instructions: Document exact wording of alarms. Clear alarms and observe recurrence pattern. Why: Repeating alarms may indicate internal sensor or control board faults.

CCR.Complaint: Incubator alarming for high temperature and not maintaining setpoint in servo mode.
CCR.Cause: Skin probe cable intermittently open; unit defaulted to uncontrolled heating response.
CCR.Resolution: Replaced skin probe with known good probe, verified stable temperature control in servo mode. Unit returned to service.

title: Dräger Isolette C2000 Infant Incubator – Humidity Not Working or Leaking
description: Troubleshooting guide for Dräger Isolette C2000 humidity system issues including low humidity, no humidity, leaks, and humidity-related alarms.

steps.title: Ensure the Infant Is Safely Relocated
steps.instructions: Transfer the patient to another properly functioning incubator. Do not troubleshoot humidity issues with an active patient inside. Humidity instability can impact thermoregulation and infection risk in neonates.

steps.title: Confirm Humidity Mode Is Enabled
steps.instructions: Verify humidity is turned ON in the control settings. Verify a target humidity level is set. Verify the system is not in a mode that disables humidification. Humidity heaters will not energize if humidity is disabled in software.

steps.title: Check Water Reservoir Level
steps.instructions: Remove and inspect the water reservoir. Confirm it contains sterile or distilled water (per facility policy). Ensure it is not empty. Ensure it is not overfilled past the maximum fill line. Observe for cracks, discoloration, warping, or mineral buildup. If empty, refill and properly reseat.

steps.title: Verify Reservoir Seating and Alignment
steps.instructions: Confirm it clicks fully into place. Confirm it sits flush with the housing. Confirm no gaps are visible. Confirm the latch (if applicable) is secure. Improper seating can prevent water from feeding to the heater, trigger false low humidity alarms, and cause external leaking.

steps.title: Inspect for External Leaks
steps.instructions: Check around the reservoir gasket or seal, bottom of the humidity compartment, under the unit base, and around drain ports if applicable. Look for water pooling, damp surfaces, or mineral residue trails. If leaking is present, remove the reservoir, inspect gasket for cracks, flattening, or debris, and clean mating surfaces.

steps.title: Check for Obstruction or Mineral Buildup
steps.instructions: Inspect the humidity chamber area without deep disassembly. Look for visible scale buildup and confirm the water pathway is not blocked. Mineral buildup can prevent proper vapor generation or water flow. If heavy buildup is suspected, remove from service for cleaning per facility procedure.

steps.title: Monitor Heater Activation Indicators
steps.instructions: With humidity enabled and reservoir properly installed, listen for normal heater cycling sounds. Monitor humidity percentage increase over 10–15 minutes. Check for error codes. If humidity does not increase at all, the heater does not appear to energize, or alarms persist, the issue may involve the humidity heater element, temperature sensor, or control board.

steps.title: Check Environmental Factors
steps.instructions: Confirm room temperature is within normal operating range. Confirm access doors and portholes are fully closed. Confirm gaskets around doors are intact. Open panels or poor sealing can cause humidity loss that mimics system failure.

CCR.Complaint: NICU staff reported humidity not increasing above 30% and water leaking from base of incubator.
CCR.Cause: Water reservoir improperly seated; gasket folded under lip causing leak and poor water feed to heater.
CCR.Resolution: Reseated reservoir properly, corrected gasket alignment, verified humidity increased to setpoint (60%) within 15 minutes. No further leakage observed. Returned unit to service.

title: Dräger Babylog VN500 Ventilator Circuit Leak / High Leak Alarm Troubleshooting
description: Guide to troubleshoot high leak or circuit leak alarms on Dräger Babylog VN500 ventilators, focusing on external causes first.

steps.title: Check Patient Connection
steps.instructions: Ensure all tubing, endotracheal or tracheostomy connections are secure. Inspect for loose or disconnected connectors at the Y-piece and patient interface. Why: Even a small disconnection can trigger a high leak alarm.

steps.title: Inspect Circuit for Damage
steps.instructions: Examine inspiratory and expiratory tubing for cracks, holes, or tears. Replace any damaged tubing immediately. Why: Damaged circuits compromise pressure delivery and tidal volume.

steps.title: Verify Humidifier and Water Trap
steps.instructions: Ensure the humidifier chamber and water trap are correctly seated. Check for condensation buildup causing unintended leaks. Why: Condensation can create low points or gaps, simulating leaks.

steps.title: Check Filters and Connectors
steps.instructions: Confirm bacterial/viral filters are correctly installed and intact. Inspect for tears, cracks, or loose fittings. Why: Faulty filters or connectors can be a source of leaks.

steps.title: Perform Circuit Leak Test
steps.instructions: Use the ventilator’s built-in leak test function. Compare measured leak with expected thresholds for the patient setup. Why: Confirms whether the leak is in the circuit versus ventilator internal components.

steps.title: Reposition or Replace Circuit Components
steps.instructions: If leak persists, systematically replace or reposition tubing, connectors, or humidifier chamber. Why: Stepwise replacement isolates the exact location of the leak.

CCR.Complaint: Patient ventilator alarms “High Leak” during therapy.
CCR.Cause: External circuit inspection revealed loose Y-piece connector and minor condensation buildup in the humidifier.
CCR.Resolution: Reconnected Y-piece, drained condensation, and verified leak within acceptable range via built-in leak test.

helpfulDetails: Outlet and gas supply pressure verified

title: Dräger Babylog VN500 Ventilator - Ventilator Won’t Deliver Breath / No Output
description: Guide for troubleshooting a Babylog VN500 ventilator that fails to deliver breaths or shows no output, focusing on external causes first.

steps.title: Verify Power Source
steps.instructions: Confirm the ventilator is connected to a live outlet or has a fully charged battery. Check the main power switch is ON. Why: No power or low battery will prevent breath delivery.

steps.title: Inspect Circuit Connections
steps.instructions: Check all patient circuit tubing for proper attachment to the ventilator ports. Ensure the inspiratory and expiratory limbs are connected correctly. Why: A disconnected or reversed circuit prevents the ventilator from delivering breaths.

steps.title: Check for Obstructions or Kinks
steps.instructions: Visually inspect the breathing circuit, filters, and tubing for kinks, occlusions, or moisture buildup. Remove any visible blockage. Why: Obstructions can trigger a no-output condition or alarm.

steps.title: Review Alarm Messages and Settings
steps.instructions: Check the ventilator display for active alarms (e.g., low pressure, high PEEP, circuit disconnection). Confirm the ventilator mode, tidal volume, and respiratory rate are correctly set. Why: Improper settings or active alarms can inhibit breath delivery.

steps.title: Circuit Leak Test
steps.instructions: Perform the ventilator’s self-test or leak check if prompted. Observe for leak indications and correct as needed. Why: Significant leaks in the circuit prevent effective ventilation.

steps.title: Confirm Gas Supply
steps.instructions: Ensure medical air and oxygen sources are available and pressure is within the acceptable range. Verify that the ventilator is properly switched to the correct gas source. Why: No or insufficient gas supply prevents breath generation.

CCR.Complaint: Ventilator is not delivering breaths to the patient.
CCR.Cause: No power issue, circuit connections verified, settings and gas supply checked; device still shows no output.
CCR.Resolution: Device removed from service, labeled Out of Service, sent for bench evaluation/repair.

title: Dräger Babylog VN500 Ventilator Touchscreen / Control Panel Issues
description: Guide for troubleshooting unresponsive or erratic touchscreen/control panel on the Babylog VN500 ventilator, focusing on external causes before escalation.

steps.title: Verify Power Source
steps.instructions: Check that the ventilator is properly connected to a reliable power outlet. Confirm that the main power switch is on and that the display is receiving power. Why: A low or intermittent power source can cause the touchscreen to behave erratically.

steps.title: Check Battery Backup (if applicable)
steps.instructions: If running on battery, ensure it is fully charged and properly seated. Switch to AC power to see if the touchscreen responds. Why: Weak batteries can reduce touchscreen responsiveness or disable the panel.

steps.title: Inspect Connections and Cables
steps.instructions: Examine the power cable and any data/control connections for damage, loose connections, or kinks. Reseat or replace cables if needed. Why: Loose or damaged connections can interrupt panel functionality.

steps.title: Restart the Device
steps.instructions: Perform a proper ventilator shutdown and restart according to Dräger guidelines. Observe if the touchscreen initializes correctly after reboot. Why: A system reset can resolve software glitches causing panel issues.

steps.title: Clean the Touchscreen Surface
steps.instructions: Use a soft, lint-free cloth slightly dampened with approved cleaning solution. Avoid excessive moisture or harsh chemicals. Why: Debris, fingerprints, or fluids on the screen can prevent accurate touch detection.

steps.title: Check for Error Messages / Panel Lock
steps.instructions: Look for any messages indicating a touchscreen or panel lock mode. Release lock or follow on-screen instructions if applicable.

steps.title: Verify Environmental Factors
steps.instructions: Ensure the ventilator is not exposed to extreme temperatures, moisture, or strong electromagnetic interference. Why: Environmental factors can affect touchscreen sensitivity or electronic circuits.

CCR.Complaint: Ventilator touchscreen not responding during routine use.
CCR.Cause: Power and connection verified; screen remains unresponsive despite reset.
CCR.Resolution: Ventilator removed from service, labeled Out of Service, sent for manufacturer repair.

helpfulDetails: Final device status documented as Out of Service

title: Mindray WATO EX Series Ventilator Alarms / No Volume Delivery
description: Guide for troubleshooting ventilator alarms and failure to deliver tidal volume on the Mindray WATO EX Series anesthesia machine.

steps.title: Verify Power and Startup
steps.instructions: Ensure the machine is connected to a reliable power source and switched on. Check that the battery (if applicable) is charged and the backup battery is functional. Why: Insufficient power can prevent the ventilator from delivering volume even if settings appear correct.

steps.title: Check Gas Supply
steps.instructions: Confirm that oxygen and air pipelines are connected and supplying correct pressures. Check pipeline pressure indicators on the machine. Why: Ventilator volume delivery requires proper gas supply; alarms often occur if pressures are too low.

steps.title: Inspect the Breathing Circuit
steps.instructions: Check for disconnections, kinks, or leaks in the inspiratory and expiratory limbs. Ensure the circuit is properly assembled and all valves are seated correctly. Why: Leaks or disconnections can prevent the set tidal volume from reaching the patient.

steps.title: Check Patient Valve and Filters
steps.instructions: Inspect the patient valve for obstruction or improper installation. Replace filters if clogged or saturated. Why: Blocked valves or filters increase resistance, reducing delivered volume.

steps.title: Verify Ventilator Settings
steps.instructions: Confirm correct mode, tidal volume, respiratory rate, and inspiratory pressure. Ensure that any patient-specific alarms or safety limits are not preventing delivery. Why: Incorrect settings or active safety limits can inhibit ventilation.

steps.title: Observe Alarms and Indicators
steps.instructions: Note any specific alarm codes or messages. Refer to the Mindray quick reference card for external checks related to the alarms. Why: Alarm codes often indicate whether the cause is mechanical, flow-related, or sensor-based.

CCR.Complaint: User reports ventilator alarm “No Volume Delivery” and patient is not receiving set tidal volume.
CCR.Cause: Upon inspection, all power, gas supply, circuit connections, and ventilator settings were verified. No external issues found; machine fails to deliver volume.
CCR.Resolution: Machine removed from service, labeled Out of Service, and sent for service/repair.

helpfulDetails: Gas pressures checked and within specification
Circuit assembled correctly, no kinks or disconnections
Machine status and settings noted prior to removal

title: Mindray WATO EX Series Gas or Agent Delivery Errors
description: Guide for troubleshooting gas or anesthetic agent delivery alarms on Mindray WATO EX Series anesthesia machines, focusing on external causes before internal component failure.

steps.title: Verify Power and Startup Sequence
steps.instructions: Ensure the machine is plugged into a properly grounded outlet and powered on. Observe the startup self-test; note any errors related to gas delivery. Why: Some delivery errors occur if the machine did not complete self-tests correctly.

steps.title: Check Gas Supply Lines
steps.instructions: Inspect O₂, N₂O, and Air pipelines for pressure and flow. Confirm cylinders are open, regulators are set correctly, and pipeline pressures are within normal range. Why: Low or no supply pressure can trigger gas delivery alarms.

steps.title: Inspect Flowmeters and Vaporizers
steps.instructions: Ensure vaporizers are seated properly and filled with the correct agent. Check for leaks at vaporizer mounts or interlocks. Verify flowmeter readings respond correctly when adjusting flows. Why: Misaligned vaporizers or empty reservoirs can prevent accurate agent delivery.

steps.title: Examine Breathing Circuit and Connectors
steps.instructions: Look for disconnections, leaks, or kinks in the circuit tubing. Confirm that the CO₂ absorber is installed correctly and not bypassed. Why: Circuit leaks can mimic gas delivery errors.

steps.title: Review Alarm and Monitoring Settings
steps.instructions: Confirm agent and gas concentration alarms are set within normal limits. Reset alarms and observe if error persists. Why: Incorrect alarm limits can give false error readings.

steps.title: Test With a Simulated Lung (if available)
steps.instructions: Run a test ventilation with a test lung using O₂ and air only. Observe delivered volumes and agent readings without a patient. Why: Helps determine if error is patient-specific or machine-related.

CCR.Complaint: Machine is displaying low agent delivery alarm and O₂/N₂O concentrations are inconsistent.
CCR.Cause: Observed vaporizer not fully seated; gas supply pressures within normal range; flowmeters respond properly when tested.
CCR.Resolution: Re-seated vaporizer and verified agent fill. Ran test lung simulation. Error resolved. Machine returned to service.

title: Mindray WATO EX Series Touchscreen / UI Issues
description: Guide for troubleshooting touchscreen and UI problems on the Mindray WATO EX Series anesthesia machine, focusing on external causes first.

steps.title: Verify Power Source
steps.instructions: Ensure the machine is properly plugged into a grounded outlet. Check the main power switch and any secondary power buttons. Why: Fluctuating or insufficient power can cause touchscreen malfunctions.

steps.title: Inspect Cables and Connections
steps.instructions: Check all external connections, including USB or auxiliary interfaces, for loose or damaged cables. Disconnect unnecessary peripherals to isolate the issue. Why: Faulty connections can interfere with the touchscreen interface.

steps.title: Check for Contamination or Obstructions
steps.instructions: Inspect the touchscreen for dirt, liquids, or residue that may prevent proper touch response. Clean gently with manufacturer-approved wipes. Why: Surface contaminants can block capacitive or resistive touch sensors.

steps.title: Restart the Machine
steps.instructions: Perform a controlled shutdown and restart. Observe whether the touchscreen responds after booting. Why: Software glitches can often be resolved with a simple reboot.

steps.title: Verify Environmental Conditions
steps.instructions: Ensure room temperature and humidity are within operational specifications. Avoid direct sunlight or strong electromagnetic interference near the touchscreen. Why: Extreme conditions can degrade touchscreen sensitivity.

steps.title: Check Software Version and Updates
steps.instructions: Verify that the device is running the latest software/firmware version. Apply updates according to Mindray procedures if accessible. Why: Older firmware can lead to UI instability or unresponsiveness.

CCR.Complaint: Touchscreen intermittently unresponsive and lagging during use.
CCR.Cause: Observed touchscreen unresponsive after verifying power, connections, and environmental conditions. No visible damage or contamination.
CCR.Resolution: Restarted the machine; issue persisted. Device removed from service and sent to repair.

helpfulDetails: All cables and peripherals disconnected and reconnected
Observed touchscreen behavior (freeze, lag, erratic response)
Final device status: Out of service
